snippet: An appeals court rightly rejected an overly broad interpretation of a computer fraud law that would have made ordinary conduct at work illegal.
abstract: Editorial applauds a federal appeals court decision rejecting an overly broad interpretation of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, which would have made ordinary conduct at work computers illegal; asserts that the anti-hacker law has been interpreted far too broadly in the past.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court rightly rejected an overly broad interpretation of a computer fraud law that would have made ordinary conduct at work illegal.
